Recovery map stability for the Data Processing Inequality

Eric A. Carlen Department of Mathematics, Hill Center, Rutgers University, 110 Frelinghuysen Road, Piscataway, NJ 08854-8019, USA Anna Vershynina Department of Mathematics, Philip Guthrie Hoffman Hall, University of Houston, 3551 Cullen Blvd., Houston, TX 77204-3008, USA
Abstract

Let â„°Ï„subscriptâ„°ğœ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} be the tracial conditional expectation from â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} onto ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}}. In fact, more is true. As is well known, every norm contractive projection is completely positive.

A conditional expectation from â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} onto ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}}, in the sense of Umegaki [41, 42, 43], is a unital projection from â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} onto ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} that is order preserving and such that (1.1) and (1.2) are satisfied. (Throughout this paper, a dagger â€ â€ \dagger always denotes the adjoint with respect to the Hilbert-Schmidt inner product.)

Let â„°Ï„subscriptâ„°ğœ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} denote the orthogonal projection from â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} onto ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} with respect to the GNS inner product determined by Ï„ğœ\tau. 1.1 Definition.

For any state ÏğœŒ\rho on â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}}, Ïğ’©subscriptğœŒğ’©\rho_{\mathcal{N}} denotes the state on ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} given by Ïğ’©:=â„°Ï„â€‹(Ï)assignsubscriptğœŒğ’©subscriptâ„°ğœğœŒ\rho_{\mathcal{N}}:={\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}(\rho) where, as always â„°Ï„subscriptâ„°ğœ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} denotes the tracial conditional expectation onto ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}}.

The restriction of a state ÏğœŒ\rho on â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} to ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} is of course a state on ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}}, and as such, it is represented by a unique density matrix belonging to ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}}, which is precisely Ïğ’©subscriptğœŒğ’©\rho_{\mathcal{N}}.

Given two states ÏğœŒ\rho and Ïƒğœ\sigma on â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}}, the Umegaki relative entropy of ÏğœŒ\rho with respect to Ïƒğœ\sigma is defined [44] by

S(Ï||Ïƒ):=Tr[Ï(logÏâˆ’logÏƒ)].S(\rho||\sigma):=\mathrm{Tr}[\rho(\log\rho-\log\sigma)]\ . (1.3)

Lindbladâ€™s inequality [19] states that with â„°Ï„subscriptâ„°ğœ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau} being the tracial conditional expectation onto ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}},

S(Ï||Ïƒ)â‰¥S(â„°Ï„(Ï)||â„°Ï„(Ïƒ)).S(\rho||\sigma)\geq S({\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}(\rho)||{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}_{\tau}(\sigma))\ . (1.4)

Lindblad showed that the monotonicity (1.4) is equivalent to the joint convexity of the relative entropy (Ï,Ïƒ)â†¦S(Ï||Ïƒ)(\rho,\sigma)\mapsto S(\rho||\sigma), and this in turn is an immediate consequence of Liebâ€™s Concavity Theorem [16]. In the case that â„³=â„¬â€‹(â„‹1âŠ—â„‹2)â„³â„¬tensor-productsubscriptâ„‹1subscriptâ„‹2{\mathcal{M}}={\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}_{1}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{2}) and ğ’©={ğŸâ„‹1âŠ—A{\mathcal{N}}=\{{\bf 1}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{1}}\otimes A, Aâˆˆâ„¬(â„‹2)}A\in{\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}_{2})\}, (1.4) was proved by Lieb and Ruskai [18], who showed it to be equivalent to the Strong Subadditivity (SSA) of the von Neumann entropy; more information on SSA is contained in SectionÂ 5.

Using the fact that Stinespingâ€™s Dilation Theorem [33] relates general CPTP maps to tracial expectation, Lindblad [20] was able to prove, using (1.4) that for any CPTP map ğ’«ğ’«{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}},

S(Ï||Ïƒ)â‰¥S(ğ’«(Ï)||ğ’«(Ïƒ)).S(\rho||\sigma)\geq S({\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}(\rho)||{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}(\sigma))\ . (1.5)

This is known as the Data Processing Inequality (DPI). Because of the simple relation between (1.4) and (1.5) the problem of determining the cases of equality in the Data Processing Inequality largely comes down the problem of determining the cases of equality in (1.4), which was solved by Petz [27, 28]. His necessary and sufficient condition for equality in (1.4) is closely connected with the problem of quantum coarse graining, and in particular a quantum coarse graining operation introduced by Acardi and Cecchini [2], whose dual is now now known as the Petz recovery channel, the CPTP map â„›Ïsubscriptâ„›ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho} given by

â„›Ïâ€‹(Î³)=Ï1/2â€‹(Ïğ’©âˆ’1/2â€‹Î³â€‹Ïğ’©âˆ’1/2)â€‹Ï1/2.subscriptâ„›ğœŒğ›¾superscriptğœŒ12superscriptsubscriptğœŒğ’©12ğ›¾superscriptsubscriptğœŒğ’©12superscriptğœŒ12{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\gamma)=\rho^{1/2}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\gamma\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2})\rho^{1/2}\ . (1.6)

It is obvious that â„›Ïâ€‹(Ïğ’©)=Ïsubscriptâ„›ğœŒsubscriptğœŒğ’©ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}})=\rho, so that â„›Ïsubscriptâ„›ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho} â€œrecoversâ€ ÏğœŒ\rho from Ïğ’©subscriptğœŒğ’©\rho_{\mathcal{N}}. Petz proved [27, 28] that there is equality in (1.4) if and only if

â„›Ïâ€‹(Ïƒğ’©)=Ïƒsubscriptâ„›ğœŒsubscriptğœğ’©ğœ{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})=\sigma (1.7)

and that this is true if and only if

â„›Ïƒâ€‹(Ïğ’©)=Ï.subscriptâ„›ğœsubscriptğœŒğ’©ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\sigma}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}})=\rho\ . (1.8)

There has been much recent work on stability for for the DPI: [13, 17, 32, 34, 35, 46]. Suppose that ÏğœŒ\rho and Ïƒğœ\sigma are such that there is approximate equality in (1.4). To what extent do ÏğœŒ\rho and Ïƒğœ\sigma provide approximate solutions to Petsâ€™s equation (1.7) and (1.8)?

1.2 Main results

In this paper we further develop an approach that we introduced in [9] for proving stability for analogs of the DPI for RÃ©nyi relative entropies. The RÃ©nyi relative entropies include the Umegaki relative entropy (1.3) as a limiting case, but taking advantage of the special structure on the Umegaki relative entropy, we are able to sharpen the stability bounds obtained in [9] for this case. Our results in this direction are given in TheoremÂ 1.5 and CorollaryÂ 1.7. These results are proved in Section 2.

Moreover, we show how the approach introduced in [9] yields a simple specification of the structure of the pairs of densities ÏğœŒ\rho and Ïƒğœ\sigma that satisfy Petzâ€™s equations (1.7) and (1.8). This is a question that was first dealt with by Hayden, Jozsa, Petz and Winter in [14]. The question arose there because, although it is known (and explained in the appendix) that the DPI is equivalent to the quantum Strong Subadditivity of the Entropy (SSA) [18], it is not so simple to translate Petzâ€™s condition for equality in the DPI into the condition for equality in SSA. This was done in [14], but Petz himself, together with Mosnyi, returned to the problem of determining the structure of solutions of (1.7) and (1.8) in [23]. Here we give simple specification of the structure of solutions providing some new information. Our main results in this direction are given in TheoremÂ 1.9 and CorollaryÂ 1.10. These results are proved in Section 3.

As explained in the next two subsections, the questions considered here are closely related to several questions concerning quantum conditional expectations and quantum â€œcoarse grainingâ€. in Section 4, we prove a theorem specifying conditions under which the orthogonal projection of â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} onto ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} is a conditional expectations, and hence, when expectation preserving conditional expectations exist. The full statement is given in TheoremÂ 4.1.

Before giving precise statements, it will be useful to recall the relatively simple situation regarding the classical DPI.

1.3 The classical DPI

It remains an open problem to prove quantum analogs of (1.12) or (1.13), even with worse constants on the right. Here we prove a quantum analog of (1.13) with a worse constant, and with the power raised from 2 to 4 on the right. The line of argument has to be entirely different from the one we have just employed in the classical case because there is no effective quantum replacement for â€œconditioning on the observable Xğ‘‹Xâ€.

It is therefore useful to find a way of describing the classical recovery map that doe not refer explicitly to conditioning on the random variable Xğ‘‹X. 1.4 Quantum conditional expectations and quantum coarse graining

1.3 Definition.

Let ÏğœŒ\rho be a faithful state on â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}}. The Accardi-Cecchini coarse graining operator ğ’œÏsubscriptğ’œğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho} from â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} to ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} is defined by (1.18).

The map ğ’œÏsubscriptğ’œğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho} was introduced by Accardi and Cecchini [2], building on previous work by Accardi [1]. The same, of course, is true for conditional expectations,

Ïâ€‹(ğ’œÏâ€‹(X))=Ïâ€‹(X).ğœŒsubscriptğ’œğœŒğ‘‹ğœŒğ‘‹\rho({\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X))=\rho(X)\ . (1.19)

Thus, unlike conditional expectations in general, the Accardi-Cecchini coarse-graining operator always preserves expectations with respect to ÏğœŒ\rho.

In the matricial setting, it is a particularly simple matter to derive an explicit expression for ğ’œÏsubscriptğ’œğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}. By definition, for all Xâˆˆâ„³ğ‘‹â„³X\in{\mathcal{M}} and all Yâˆˆğ’©ğ‘Œğ’©Y\in{\mathcal{N}},

Make the change of variables Z=Ïğ’©1/2â€‹Yâ€‹Ïğ’©1/2ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœŒğ’©12ğ‘ŒsuperscriptsubscriptğœŒğ’©12Z=\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}Y\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{1/2}. Since the above holds for all Zâˆˆğ’©ğ‘ğ’©Z\in{\mathcal{N}}, it follows that

It is evident from this formula that ğ’œÏsubscriptğ’œğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho} is a completely positive unital map from â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} to ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}}, and therefore it is actually a contraction from â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} to ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}}. That is, if Xâˆˆğ’©ğ‘‹ğ’©X\in{\mathcal{N}}, it is not necessarily the case that ğ’œÏâ€‹(X)=Xsubscriptğ’œğœŒğ‘‹ğ‘‹{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X)=X. 1.4 Definition.

The Petz recovery map â„›Ïsubscriptâ„›ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho} is the Hilbert-Schmidt adjoint of ğ’œÏsubscriptğ’œğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho} [28]. That is, â„›Ï=ğ’œÏâ€ subscriptâ„›ğœŒsuperscriptsubscriptğ’œğœŒâ€ {\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}={\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}^{\dagger}, or equivalently, for all density matrices Î³âˆˆğ’©ğ›¾ğ’©\gamma\in{\mathcal{N}}

Trâ€‹[Î³â€‹ğ’œÏâ€‹(X)]=Trâ€‹[â„›Ïâ€‹(Î³)â€‹X].Trdelimited-[]ğ›¾subscriptğ’œğœŒğ‘‹Trdelimited-[]subscriptâ„›ğœŒğ›¾ğ‘‹\mathrm{Tr}[\gamma{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(X)]=\mathrm{Tr}[{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\gamma)X]\ .

A dagger â€ â€ \dagger always denotes the adjoint with respect to the Hilbert-Schmidt inner product.

As the dual of a unital completely positive map, â„›Ïsubscriptâ„›ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho} is a CPTP map. Moreover, it follows immediately from the definition and (1.22) that for all density matrices Î³âˆˆğ’©ğ›¾ğ’©\gamma\in{\mathcal{N}},

â„›Ïâ€‹(Î³)=Ï1/2â€‹(Ïğ’©âˆ’1/2â€‹Î³â€‹Ïğ’©âˆ’1/2)â€‹Ï1/2.subscriptâ„›ğœŒğ›¾superscriptğœŒ12superscriptsubscriptğœŒğ’©12ğ›¾superscriptsubscriptğœŒğ’©12superscriptğœŒ12{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\gamma)=\rho^{1/2}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2}\gamma\rho_{\mathcal{N}}^{-1/2})\rho^{1/2}\ . (1.23)

It is evident from this formula not only that â„›Ïsubscriptâ„›ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho} is a CPTP map, but that â„›Ïâ€‹(Ïğ’©)=Ïsubscriptâ„›ğœŒsubscriptğœŒğ’©ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}})=\rho; i.e., â„›Ïsubscriptâ„›ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho} recovers ÏğœŒ\rho from Ïğ’©subscriptğœŒğ’©\rho_{\mathcal{N}}. Now suppose that Ïƒğœ\sigma is another density matrix in â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} and that

â„›Ïâ€‹(Ïƒğ’©)=Ïƒ.subscriptâ„›ğœŒsubscriptğœğ’©ğœ{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})=\sigma\ . (1.24)

Then by the Data Processing Inequality and (1.24), S(Ï||Ïƒ)â‰¤S(â„›Ï(Ïğ’©)||â„›Ï(Ïƒğ’©))=S(Ï||Ïƒ)S(\rho||\sigma)\leq S({\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\rho_{\mathcal{N}})||{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}))=S(\rho||\sigma). Hence when â„›Ïâ€‹(Ïƒğ’©)=Ïƒsubscriptâ„›ğœŒsubscriptğœğ’©ğœ{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})=\sigma, there is equality in (1.4). The deeper result of Petz [27, 28] is that there is equality in (1.4) only in this case.

Our goal is to prove a stability bound for Petzâ€™s theorem on the cases of equality in (1.4). Our result involves the relative modular operator Î”Ï,ÏƒsubscriptÎ”ğœŒğœ\Delta_{\rho,\sigma} on â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} defined by

for all Xâˆˆâ„³ğ‘‹â„³X\in{\mathcal{M}}. This is the matricial version of an operator introduced in a more general von Neumann algebra context by Araki [3]. Our main result is:

We close the introduction with some further comments on recovery map stability bounds for the Data Processing Inequality. In physical applications, instead of the trace distance, one often consider an alternative measure of the closeness between two quantum states, the fidelity [39]. For two states ÏğœŒ\rho and Ïƒğœ\sigma on â„¬â€‹(â„‹)â„¬â„‹{\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}), the fidelity between them is defined as

Fâ€‹(Ï,Ïƒ)=â€–Ïâ€‹Ïƒâ€–12.ğ¹ğœŒğœsuperscriptsubscriptnormğœŒğœ12F(\rho,\sigma)=\|\sqrt{\rho}\sqrt{\sigma}\|_{1}^{2}. (1.41)

For all states ÏğœŒ\rho and Ïƒğœ\sigma, we have 0â‰¤Fâ€‹(Ï,Ïƒ)â‰¤10ğ¹ğœŒğœ10\leq F(\rho,\sigma)\leq 1. The fidelity equal to one if and only if the states are equal, and it is equal to zero if and only is the support of ÏğœŒ\rho is orthogonal to the support of Ïƒğœ\sigma. So in other words, the fidelity is zero when states are perfectly distinguishable, and zero when they cannot be distinguished. Note that the fidelity itself satisfies the monotonicity relation under a completely positive trace preserving maps, but we will not discuss it here. Moreover, there is a relation between the trace distance â€–Ïâˆ’Ïƒâ€–1subscriptnormğœŒğœ1\|\rho-\sigma\|_{1} and fidelity

1âˆ’Fâ€‹(Ï,Ïƒ)â‰¤12â€‹â€–Ïâˆ’Ïƒâ€–1â‰¤1âˆ’Fâ€‹(Ï,Ïƒ).1ğ¹ğœŒğœ12subscriptnormğœŒğœ11ğ¹ğœŒğœ1-\sqrt{F(\rho,\sigma)}\leq\frac{1}{2}\|\rho-\sigma\|_{1}\leq\sqrt{1-F(\rho,\sigma)}\ . (1.42)

From here and the Corollary 1.7 we obtain the quantitative version of the Petzâ€™s Theorem involving the fidelity between states

S(Ï||Ïƒ)âˆ’S(Ïğ’©||Ïƒğ’©)â‰¥(Ï€4)4âˆ¥Î”Ïƒ,Ïâˆ¥âˆ’2(1âˆ’Fâ€‹(Ïƒ,â„›Ïâ€‹(Ïƒğ’©)))4.S(\rho||\sigma)-S(\rho_{\mathcal{N}}||\sigma_{\mathcal{N}})\geq\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)^{4}\|\Delta_{\sigma,\rho}\|^{-2}\left(1-\sqrt{F(\sigma,{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}))}\right)^{4}\ . (1.43)

Recent results [13, 17, 45, 46] provide sharpening of the monotonicity inequality, but the lower bounds provided there involve quantities that are hard to compute, e.g. rotated and twirled Petz recovery maps. for another fidelity type bound not explicitly involving the recover map, see [8, Theorem 2.2]. The appeal of the above bound is that it involves simple distance measure between the original state Ïƒğœ\sigma and Petz recovered state â„›Ïâ€‹(Ïƒğ’©)subscriptâ„›ğœŒsubscriptğœğ’©{\mathord{\mathscr{R}}}_{\rho}(\sigma_{\mathcal{N}}).

3 Structure of the solution set of the Petz equation

The problem of determining all of the states fixed by Î¦Î¦\Phi is closely related to the problem of determining all of the fixed points of Î¨Î¨\Psi in â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}}. This problem has been investigated in a general context by Lindblad [21] in the proof of his General No-cloning Theorem, drawing on earlier work by Choi and Kadison. It was also investigated in this specific context by Accardi and Cecchini. For now, we need not assume that Î¨Î¨\Psi is given by (3.2). 3.1 Lemma.

3.3 Theorem.

4 Conditional expectations

Recall from the introduction that if ÏğœŒ\rho is a faithful state on â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} and ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} is a von Neumann subalgebra of â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}}, then there exists a conditional expectation â„°â„°{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}} from â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} to ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} such that for all Xâˆˆâ„³ğ‘‹â„³X\in{\mathcal{M}}, Ïâ€‹(X)=Ïâ€‹(â„°â€‹(X))ğœŒğ‘‹ğœŒâ„°ğ‘‹\rho(X)=\rho({\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}(X)) if and only if the orthogonal projection onto ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} in the GNS inner product induced by ÏğœŒ\rho is a conditional expectation.

This raises the question: For which faithful states ÏğœŒ\rho is the orthogonal projection onto ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} in the GNS inner product induced by ÏğœŒ\rho is actually a conditional expectation?

4.1 Theorem.

Let â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} be a finite dimensional von Neumann algebra, and let ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} be a von Neumann subalgebra of â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}}. Let ÏğœŒ\rho be a faithful state on â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}}, and let Î”ÏsubscriptÎ”ğœŒ\Delta_{\rho} be the modular operator on â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} defined by Î”Ïâ€‹(X)=Ïâ€‹Xâ€‹Ïâˆ’1subscriptÎ”ğœŒğ‘‹ğœŒğ‘‹superscriptğœŒ1\Delta_{\rho}(X)=\rho X\rho^{-1}. Let ğ’«Ïsubscriptğ’«ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} be the orthogonal projection from â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} onto ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} in the GNS inner product induced by ÏğœŒ\rho. Then:

(1) ğ’«Ïsubscriptğ’«ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is real; i.e., it preserves self-adjointness, if and only if ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} is invariant under Î”ÏsubscriptÎ”ğœŒ\Delta_{\rho}.

(2) ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} is invariant under Î”ÏsubscriptÎ”ğœŒ\Delta_{\rho} if and only if for all Aâˆˆğ’©ğ´ğ’©A\in{\mathcal{N}},

Î”Ïâ€‹(A)=Î”Ïğ’©â€‹(A),subscriptÎ”ğœŒğ´subscriptÎ”subscriptğœŒğ’©ğ´\Delta_{\rho}(A)=\Delta_{\rho_{\mathcal{N}}}(A)\ , (4.1)

in which case Î”Ïtâ€‹(A)=Î”Ïğ’©tâ€‹(A)subscriptsuperscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğœŒğ´subscriptsuperscriptÎ”ğ‘¡subscriptğœŒğ’©ğ´\Delta^{t}_{\rho}(A)=\Delta^{t}_{\rho_{\mathcal{N}}}(A) for all tâˆˆâ„ğ‘¡â„t\in{\mathbb{R}}. Furthermore, (4.1) is valid for all Aâˆˆğ’©ğ´ğ’©A\in{\mathcal{N}} if and only if ğ’œÏâ€‹(A)=Asubscriptğ’œğœŒğ´ğ´{\mathord{\mathscr{A}}}_{\rho}(A)=A for all Aâˆˆğ’©ğ´ğ’©A\in{\mathcal{N}}.

Hence ğ’«Ïsubscriptğ’«ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is a conditional expectation. By what we proved earlier, this means that ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} is invariant under Î”ÏsubscriptÎ”ğœŒ\Delta_{\rho}, and then that (4.1) is valid for all Aâˆˆğ’©ğ´ğ’©A\in{\mathcal{N}}. âˆ

4.3 Theorem.

Let ğ’«Ïsubscriptğ’«ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} denote the orthogonal projection of â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} onto ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} in the GNS inner product induced by ÏğœŒ\rho. Then

(1) ğ’«Ïsubscriptğ’«ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is a conditional expectation if and only if ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} is invariant under Î”ÏsubscriptÎ”ğœŒ\Delta_{\rho}.

(2) ğ’«Ïsubscriptğ’«ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is a conditional expectation if and only if ğ’«Ïsubscriptğ’«ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is real.

Proof.

TheoremÂ 4.1 says that when Î”ÏsubscriptÎ”ğœŒ\Delta_{\rho} does not leave ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} invariant, ğ’«Ïsubscriptğ’«ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is not even real, and hence is not a conditional expectation. On the other hand, when Î”ÏsubscriptÎ”ğœŒ\Delta_{\rho} leaves ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} invariant, a theorem of Takesaki says that there exists a projection â„°â„°{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}} with unit norm from â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}} onto ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} that satisfies (1.15). By Tomiyamaâ€™s Theorem and remarks we have made in the introduction, this means that â„°=ğ’«Ïâ„°subscriptğ’«ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{E}}}={\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho}, and that ğ’«Ïsubscriptğ’«ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is a conditional expectation in the sense of Umegaki. This proves (1).

It is evident that if ğ’«Ïsubscriptğ’«ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is a conditional expectation, this ğ’«Ïsubscriptğ’«ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is real. On the other hand, if ğ’«Ïsubscriptğ’«ğœŒ{\mathord{\mathscr{P}}}_{\rho} is real, then by TheoremÂ 4.1, ğ’©ğ’©{\mathcal{N}} is invariant under Î”ÏsubscriptÎ”ğœŒ\Delta_{\rho}, and now (2) follows from (1). âˆ

5 Strong Subadditivity

S(Ï12||Ï1âŠ—Ï2)â‰¤S(Ï123||Ï1âŠ—Ï23),S(\rho_{12}||\rho_{1}\otimes\rho_{2})\leq S(\rho_{123}||\rho_{1}\otimes\rho_{23}), (5.1)

where Ï12=Trâ„‹3â€‹Ï123subscriptğœŒ12subscriptTrsubscriptâ„‹3subscriptğœŒ123\rho_{12}=\mathrm{Tr}_{{\mathcal{H}}_{3}}\rho_{123} etc. (See [18]). With ğ’©:=â„¬â€‹(â„‹1âŠ—â„‹2)assignğ’©â„¬tensor-productsubscriptâ„‹1subscriptâ„‹2{\mathcal{N}}:={\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}_{1}\otimes{\mathcal{H}}_{2}),

The DPI inequality yields

for Ï,Ïƒâˆˆâ„¬â€‹(â„‹)ğœŒğœâ„¬â„‹\rho,\sigma\in{\mathcal{B}}({\mathcal{H}}).

The stability bound proved here has obvious consequences for the SSA inequality, and can be used to give a quantitative version of the result [14] of Hayden, Josza, Petz and Winter. For another improvement to the SSA inequality, namely

Sâ€‹(Ï12)+Sâ€‹(Ï23)âˆ’Sâ€‹(Ï123)âˆ’Sâ€‹(Ï2)â‰¥2â€‹maxâ¡{Sâ€‹(Ï1)âˆ’Sâ€‹(Ï13),Sâ€‹(Ï3)âˆ’Sâ€‹(Ï13)},ğ‘†subscriptğœŒ12ğ‘†subscriptğœŒ23ğ‘†subscriptğœŒ123ğ‘†subscriptğœŒ22ğ‘†subscriptğœŒ1ğ‘†subscriptğœŒ13ğ‘†subscriptğœŒ3ğ‘†subscriptğœŒ13S(\rho_{12})+S(\rho_{23})-S(\rho_{123})-S(\rho_{2})\geq 2\max\{S(\rho_{1})-S(\rho_{13}),S(\rho_{3})-S(\rho_{13})\}\ , (5.11)

see [7].
